subject: Are You Ready for Some Football?
event:
NFL football returns in a couple of hours, so life will have meaning again.

I will watch tonight's game between the Steelers and Dolphins, of course, since it's the season opener, but I really don't have a horse in that contest.  I'm saving my real energy for the weekend, when the Giants and the Jets take the field for the first time.

Big Blue and Gang Green are my guys.  Yeah, both of them.  Sometimes people ask me how I can possibly root for them both, since they're rivals and all.  All I can say is that I am very, very old.  When I was growing up in Jersey, the G-Men were the only NYC team, so of course I cheered for them.  Later, when the Jets came along, they were in an entirely different league and never played the Giants, so I started cheering for them too... especially after they got that Namath guy.  I do have a crisis once every three years when they play each other, but I can deal with that.  My dream is to live long enough to see a Subway Superbowl.

This year the Giants are expected to be a Superbowl contender, and the Jets are expected to vie for the first pick in next year's draft.  Two years ago the Jets were a Superbowl contender and the Giants were contending for the first pick in the draft.  See, it's good to have two teams.  Every weekend, I have two chances at happiness.  If both teams win, I'm thrilled.  If one wins and one loses, I am heartened by the victory.  It's only when both of them lose that I tell Parris that life is meaningless and there is no joy in Mudville.

As for predicting what the season will be like... somehow I think the Jets are going to be better than anyone expects, but I'm not sure that the Giants are going to be as good.  The Giants have always seemed to have their best seasons when everyone expects them to stink.  When the experts pick them to win, somehow they usually tank.

But maybe not.  So much depends on Eli.  We'll see how the first game goes, when they face the mighty Colts in the Manning Bowl.

Are you ready for some football?

comments.article: I am indeed ready to watch the Panthers march to the Superbowl. *nods*
I'm with you, the Panthers have this season on lock...it's basically going to be amazing.
Ooo, ooo, I'm not, I'm not!

I hate all things Manning, so I can't root for the NY Giants. Which is tough, because I really like and respect Tiki Barber. I expect the NY Giants to do well, if for no reason than because I spent all my anti-Manning karma when the Steelers pulled off that upset victory against Peyton and the Colts in the playoffs. And, while the Giants are in a tough division (well... tough for the NFC), I think they've got an equal if not better chance against the Cowboys and Eagles.

The Jets however... no matter if they're underrated or not, they've still got to deal with the Pats (and maybe even the Dolphins) in their division. And based on the way the Pats manhandled the Redskins in the preseason, I don't think they've lost much with the loss of key players (McGinest, Vinatieri, probably Branch) in the off-season.
I would pay good money to see Peyton get eaten by rabid geese. Eli has yet to earn that fate in my eyes...

Honestly, I think football is one of the more stupid achievements of mankind. Watching it is even worse than playing it. *laughs* But I trust you'll enjoy yourself, which is what it's there for: entertainment.
ezactly.

comments.upictitle: Life is not a song, Sansa Stark: yankees
comments.article:
I get the same question in baseball - I'm a Yankees fan but am pro-Met when they're not playing the Yankees. In football, though, I mildly anti-Giant. Despite friends of mine's insistance that the cross-town rivalry is WORSE with baseball.

Um, okay? I'm a Yankees fan and a Jets fan. Clearly my allegiances do not follow the norm.

Lastly, I hope you're right about the Jets!

Am I ever, George.

And when the Jets are 1-14, just remember that one of your most devoted fans is a Packer fan. Hey, at least misery will most likely have company this year.

Just wanted to say I too am a devoted Packers fan, and I will be seeing my 1st game in Lambeau Field this November. My husband wants to see them play there before Brett Favre retires. They're not looking to do too well this year, sadly, but we fans stay true all the same.

-A
As long as the g** d*** refs don't screw up the Superbowl like they did for the Seahawks, I will be happy. Seahawk fans (and I count myself among them) are still mad at what happened.

We all know that the real football is not the one played over in the US =P What you play is a weird kind of Ruby with shoulder-pads. Still, I am looking forward to seeing the Redskins get a generous ass whooping this season (my wife's family's team)

comments.upictitle: Jeanne / Xaviara al'Nady / Tita Kini: PolarBear
comments.article:
You betcha!! But I'm a KC Chiefs fan. I was in the parade the day Lamar Hunt brought the team to KC (marching band) and went to two superbowls with them. That was when they had the great Hank Stram as coach with Len Dawson, Ed Podalak, Bobby Bell, Jan Stenerud, Otis Taylor, need I go on? I did my stint in the Chiefettes my senior year in high school. Those were the good old days. My family still has charter season tickets that I get to enjoy when I manage to make it home on a football game weekend. This year they have a new coach, Herm Edwards who used to coach the Jets, so it should be interesting. I'm not expecting a lot out of them, but hey, I'm loyal. They say whatever team you rooted for when you were 12 years old is your team for life. Sounds like that's true for both of us!

I now live in Jets/Giants territory (Westchester, New York). I'm a Mets fan by default because I could never be a Yankee fan. I'm probably a Jets fan just because of the Broadway Joe era that I enjoyed. Not terribly fond of either Manning brother.

So bring on the nachos and hot chocolate!!

comments.upictitle: Popular series of fiction, fancy, and fact.: Benevolent sense of life
comments.article: That's the one where they wear helmets, right?

The Jets?? I am sorry to say but my boys are going to rough them up a bit. ;)

But then again, the Jets have a player named D'Brickashaw, which is quite possibly the most magical football name EVER, so you never know.

On a side note, I can't believe my favorite author (tied with John Irving I have to say) loves football. How cool is that?

D'Brick has a pretty cool name, but "Pork Chop" Womack and "Booger" McFarland have better ones.

And I always liked the Aussie rules player they called "the Flying Doormat."
comments.subject: football names

comments.article: I'm a Packer fan.  While the preseason lasts I could entertain hope that Farve will be able to have a respectable final season I'm afraid that those dreams will be crushed by the end of September.
How do I know you're not a Packers fan? You spell "Favre" wrong.
My office has a fantasy league.  They are pretty hardcore about it.  Hardcore to the point that a few people called in sick the day after draft picks last week.
My super bowl has the Bills representing the AFC.  The game is interrupted when Satan shows up at halftime, heralded by a mighty blizzard, to pick up the check.

My dream is to live long enough to see a Subway Superbowl.

Got no interest in football at all - except soccer that is. Don't know or understand the reasons or rationale behind football despite being born in and living in the US most of my life, and could really not care less than I already do.

But. Your comment, quoted above. I grew up with baseball, in the Bay Area. And in 1989, the World Series for the first and last time was the Bay Series, Oakland versus San Francisco. Surely I don't have to remind you what happened then? Game 3, in SF, 5:04 PM, October 17th - The Big Enough One, as my friends and I have ever after called it; Loma Prieta, to non-participants, 7.3 magnitude.

I grew up in Oakland, but had moved to SF 9 years before this event, and I'd switched my allegience from the A's to the Giants. The Giants, who were ahead at that point in the series, lost ignominiously when play resumed some weeks later. And SF and the Bay Area recovered and rebuilt.

But would you really wish such calamity on your chosen teams?
Wow, one of those "do you remember where you were when it happened" moments.

I am so ready for football, I already painted my body silver.

Go Raiders!! (and Vikings!)
I hope I was part of that silver body painting... :D

I agree George life has meaning again at least until the end of January. Enjoy your work, website, and the way you keep us fans
informed.
Jackin around
